text: Great Stambridge is a village and former civil parish, south east of Chelmsford, now in the parish of Stambridge, in the Rochford district, in the county of Essex, England. In 1931 the parish had a population of 355. == Features == Great Stambridge has a church called St Mary & All Saints and a pub called The Royal Oak. == History == The name "Stambridge" means 'Stone bridge'. Great Stambridge was recorded in the Domesday Book as Sanforda. Great Stambridge had 3 manors, Great Stambridge Hall, Hampton-Barns and Bretton.Essex ac.uk Great Stambridge was in the Rochford hundred. On 1 April 1934 the parish was abolished and merged with Little Stambridge to form Stambridge parish. == References == ==External links== * * Category:Villages in Essex Category:Former civil parishes in Essex Category:Rochford District
title: Great Stambridge
